paragraphs.context: Both X.25 and Frame Relay provide connection-driven operations. But the X.25 will do it on the network layer of the OSI model. Frame Relay does it on level two, the data link layer. Another important difference between X.25 and Frame Relay is that X.25 requires a handshake between the parties responsible for communication before sending the user packages. Frame Relay doesn't define handshakes like this. X.25 does not specify any functions in the package network. It only works on the user-network interface (UNI). Therefore, the network provider is free to use any method he wishes to use within the network. X.25 defines some limited retransmission procedures within the UNI and its LAPB protocol (link layer protocol) provides standard HDLC-type link management procedures. Frame Relay is a modified version of ISDN's dual-layer protocol, LAPD and LAPB. Therefore, its integrity functions only concern the link between nodes, not between them. All retransmissions shall be carried out by means of a higher layer protocols. The X.25 UNI protocol is part of the X.25 protocol series consisting of three lower layers of the OSI model. It was widely used in the UNI in parcel exchange networks in the early 1980s and 1990s in order to establish a standardised interface with and beyond the parcel networks. Some of the projects also used X.25 within the network, but its associated features made the installation difficult and ineffective. Frame-rele works mainly on the second floor of the OSI model. However, the Data Link Connection ID (DLCI) may be used in the OSI network layer using minimum methods. Thus, it is rid of many X.25 layers with 3 layers, but DLCI is still an identifier that crosses the node-to-node-level two-link protocol. The simplicity of Frame Relay makes it faster and more efficient than X.25. Since Frame relay is a data link layer protocol such as X.25, it does not define intra-net routing functions. For X.25, its package identifiers – the virtual circuit and virtual channel numbers must be correlated to the URLs. The same applies to Frame Relays DLCI. How this is done depends on the network provider. Frame Relay, as no network layer procedures exist, is connected to layer two, using HDLC/LAPD/LAPB Set Asynchronous Balanced Mode (SABM). An X.25 connection is typically created for each communication session, but it has a feature that allows a limited amount of traffic through the UNI without any connection-oriented handshake. For some time Frame Relay was used to connect LAN networks between large-scale networks. However, X.25 and Frame Relay have been replaced by Internet Protocol (IP) on the network layer and by Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) or multi-proximity ID switch (MPLS) versions on the second layer. Typical configuration is running an IP over an ATM or an MPLS version. <Uyless Black, X.25 and related protocols, IEEE Computer Society, 1991 > <Uyless Black, Frame Relay Networks, McGraw-Hill, 1998 <Uyless Black, MPLS and Label Switching Networks, Prentice Hall, 2001> < Uyless Black, ATM, Part 1, Prentice Hall, 1995 >

paragraphs.context: There are three main types of stones: magnets, sediments and metamorphics. The rock cycle is an important concept of geology, which describes the relationship between these three types of rock and magma. When the stone crystallises by melting (magma and/or lava), it is a fine stone. This stone can be saved and dried, then stored and flattened into sedimentary stone, or transformed into a stone because of heat and pressure, which changes the mineral content of the rock, giving it a characteristic fabric. The sedimentary rock can then be transformed into a shape-shifting stone by heat and pressure, after which it is saved, decomposed, layered, and flattened and eventually transformed into a sedimentary stone. The sedimentary stone can also be plastered and stored again, and the metamorphic stone can also be changed. All three kinds of stones can be remelted; when this happens, a new magma is formed, from which magma can crystallize again.

paragraphs.context: Following the principle of benefit for most people, economic inequality is a problem. A house that offers a millionaire less benefit as a summer home than a five-person homeless family is an example of a decline in society's "distributive efficiency" that reduces the marginal benefits of wealth and thus the sum of personal benefits. An additional dollar spent by a poor person goes to things that bring him great benefits, such as basic needs such as food, water and health care, while an extra dollar spent by a much richer person is very likely to go to luxury goods that offer him relatively less benefit. This reduces the marginal benefit of wealth per person ("additional dollar") as the person becomes richer. From this point of view, the wealth of society has a greater overall benefit in a society with more equality. Some studies have found evidence of this theory and found that in societies where inequalities are lower, population satisfaction and happiness are generally higher.

According to the terms of the association, schools had to have courses comparable to the university, notify the university in advance of any planned faculty meetings or layoffs, not book a faculty without the approval of the university, and send copies of the tests for proposals. The University of Chicago agreed to give a degree to all university graduates who completed an A degree for four years and to all other graduates who completed 12 weeks of additional studies at the University of Chicago. At the University of Chicago, a student or a member of the faculty was entitled to a free tuition fee, and Chicago students were entitled to attend the same school on the same terms and to receive recognition for their work. The University of Chicago also agreed to offer books and scientific equipment and supplies at any cost to schools, special teachers and lecturers without expenses except travel expenses, and a copy of each book and magazine published by the University of Chicago free of charge. paragraphs.context: Yuan dynasty (Chinese; Phinyin: Yuán Cháo), officially large Yuan (Chinese: Phinyin): Dà Yuán; Mongolian: Yee Yuan Ulus[a]) was the Chinese Empire or the ruling dynasty founded by Kublai Khan, leader of the Mongolian Borjig clan. Although the Mongols had dominated the territories, including today’s North China, the Kublai Khan officially declared the dynasty in the traditional Chinese style only in 1271. At this point his kingdom was isolated from other khanas and dominated by most of the present China and its immediate areas, such as modern Mongolia and Korea. It was the first foreign dynasty to rule over the whole of China and lasted until 1368, after which its Genghisid rulers returned to their homeland of Mongolia and continued to rule the North Yuan dynasty. Ögedei offered his nephew Kublai a place in Xingzhou, Hebei. Kublai could not read Chinese, but he was accompanied by several Han-Chinese teachers from the early years of his mother Sorghagtan. T-cells only identify a "non-self" target, such as a pathogen, after treatment and presentation of antigens (small pieces of pathogen) together with a "self-self" receptor called a significant histocompatibility complex (MHC). There are two main types of T-cells: the killer T-cell and the helper T-cell. In addition, there are regulated T-cells that are relevant to the modification of the immune response. Killer T-cells only recognise antigens associated with IHC molecules, while helper T-cells and regulating T-cells only identify antigens associated with Class II MHC molecules. These two antigen presentations reflect the different roles of the two types of T-cells. A third minor subtype is T-cells that identify intact antigens that do not bind to MHC receptors.

paragraphs.context: Killer T-cells are sub-group T-cells that kill infected or otherwise damaged or incapacitated cells with viruses (and other pathogens). Like B-cells, each type of T-cell recognizes a different antigen. Killer T-cells are activated when their T-cell receptor (TCR) binds to this specific antigen in a complex with a second cell MHC class I receptor. The recognition of this MHC antigen complex is supported by the T-cell's second receptor, CD8. The T-cell then travels throughout the body looking for cells in which MHC I receptors carry this antigen. When an activated T-cell contacts such cells, it releases cytotoxics, such as perforin, which form pores in the target cell plasma membrane, allowing ions, water and poisons to enter. The transfer of another toxin (protease) called granulysin causes target cell apoptosis. Killing T-cells in host cells is particularly important in preventing viral reproduction. T-cell activation is strictly controlled and usually requires a very strong MHC/antigen activation signal or additional activation signals given by the "helper" T-cells (see below).

paragraphs.context: Helicopter T-cells express T-cell receptors that identify a antigen bound to Class II MHC molecules. The MHC antigen complex is also identified by the helper cell CD4 combination receptor, which recruits molecules (e.g. Lck) responsible for T-cell activation. Helicopter T cells have a weaker connection to the MHC antigen complex than killer T cells, which means that many T-cell receptors (about 200-300) of the adjutant cell must be bound to the MHC antigen in order to activate the adjutant cell, while the T-cells of the killer can be activated by a single MHC antigen molecule. The activation of the Heliper T cell also requires a longer period of time with the antigen-presenting cell. The activation of the T-cell by the rest-assisted device causes it to release cytokines that affect the function of many cell types. Cytokine signals produced by assistant T-cells enhance the microbial activity of macrophages and the activity of killer T-cells. In addition, helper T cell activation increases the regulation of molecules on the surface of the T-cell, such as CD40 ligand (also called CD154), providing additional stimulatory signals typically needed to activate antibodies-producing B cells.

paragraphs.context: Gammadelta T-cells (T-cells) have an alternative T-cell receptor (TCR) against CD4+ and CD8+ cells and have the properties of T-cells, cytotoxic T-cells and NK cells. The conditions for T-cell response are not fully understood. Like other "unconventional" T-cells with invariant TCR cells, such as CD1d-limited Natural Killer T-cells, including T-cells, run at the limit of congenital and adaptive immunity. On the other hand, T-cells are part of an adaptive immunity when they modify TCR genes to produce receptor diversity and can also develop a phenotype of memory. On the other hand, different subgroups are also part of the congenital immune system, since limited TCR or NK receptors can be used as pattern recognition receptors. For example, a large number of human V.9/V.2 T-cells respond within hours to the usual molecules produced by microbes, and very limited V.1+ T-cells react to stressed epithelial cells in epithelial cells.

paragraphs.context: A B cell identifies pathogens when antibodies on its surface bind to a specific foreign antigen. This antigen/antibody complex is transferred to the B cell and treated with proteolysis as peptides. The B cell then contains these antigen peptides in MHC class II molecules. This combination of MHC and antigen attracts a suitable helper T cell that releases lymphokins and activates the B cell. When the activated B cell then begins to divide, its offspring (plasma cells) secrete millions of copies of the antibody that recognizes this antigen. These antibodies circulate in plasma and lymph nodes, bind to antigen-expressing pathogens and indicate that they are destroyed by complement activation or into the uptake and destruction of phagocytes. Antibodies can also neutralise challenges directly, by binding to bacterial poisons or by interfering with receptors used by viruses and bacteria to infect cells.

paragraphs.context: When B and T cells become activated and multiply, some of their offspring become long-lived memory cells. Throughout the life of the animal, these memory cells remember every pathogen they encounter and may have a strong response if the pathogen is re-occurred. This is "adaptable" because it occurs during the lifetime of the individual as an adaptation to the infection caused by the pathogen and prepares the immune system for future challenges. Immunological memory can be either in the form of passive short-term memory or active long-term memory.

paragraphs.context: New-born children have no prior exposure to microbes and are particularly susceptible to infection. Mother has several layers of passive protection. During pregnancy, a certain type of antibody, IgG, passes directly from the mother to the child through the placenta, so that human babies have high levels of antibodies even at birth, and the differences in antigens are the same as the mother. Breast milk or colostrum also contains antibodies that pass into the intestines of the infant and protect against bacterial infections until the newborn can synthesize its own antibodies. This is a passive immunity because the fetus does not actually make memory cells or antibodies, but simply borrow them. This passive immunity is usually of short duration and lasts for a few days to several months. Passive immunity that protects medicine can also be artificially transferred from one individual to another by means of an antibody-containing serum.

paragraphs.context: Hormones can act as immunomodulators, which alters the sensitivity of the immune system. For example, female sex hormones are immunostimulators of both anadaptive and congenital immune responses. Some autoimmune diseases, such as lupus erythematosus, primarily strike women, and their onset often occurs at the same time as puberty. In contrast, male sex hormones, such as testosterone, appear to be immunosuppressive. Other hormones also appear to regulate the immune system, especially prolactin, growth hormone and vitamin D.

In addition, proteins such as NFIL3, which have been shown to be closely intertwined with the differentiation of T-cells and our daily rhythms, can affect the disruption of natural light and dark periods due to sleep deprivation, shift work, etc. As a result, these disorders can lead to an increase in chronic diseases such as heart disease, chronic pain and asthma.

paragraphs.context: It has been thought that the progressive reduction in hormone levels with age is partly the cause of a weakened immune response in older people. On the other hand, the immune system regulates some hormones, especially thyroid hormone. Age-related immune impairment is also associated with decreased vitamin D levels in the elderly. As people age, there are two things that have a negative effect on their vitamin D levels. First of all, they remain indoors more because of the fall in activity levels. This means that they receive less sun and thus produce less cholecalciferol through UVB radiation. Secondly, as humans age, the skin is no longer as good at producing vitamin D.

paragraphs.context: The immune system primarily responds to tumours by destroying abnormal cells with killer T cells, sometimes with helper T cells. Tumour antigens are present in MHC class I molecules in the same way as viral antigens. This is how the killer's T-cells identify the tumor cell as abnormal. NK cells also kill tumour cells in the same way, especially if the tumour cells contain fewer MHC class I molecules than normal; this is a common tumour phenomenon. Sometimes antibodies are created against tumour cells, which allows them to be destroyed in the complement system.

paragraphs.context: Unlike animals, plants do not have phagocytic cells, but many plant immune responses are accompanied by systemic chemical signals that are transmitted through the plant. Individual plant cells react to pathogens called pathogen-related molecular models or PAMP models. When part of the plant becomes infected, the plant produces a local hypersensitivity response in which the cells at the site of infection quickly enter apoptosis to prevent the spread of the disease to other parts of the plant. Systemic acquired resistance (SAR) is a plant defence response that makes the whole plant resistant to a specific infectious agent. RNA silencing mechanisms are particularly important in this systemic response as they may inhibit viral replication.

paragraphs.context: Overactive immune responses are the other end of the immune disorder, especially autoimmune diseases. Here the immune system cannot properly distinguish itself and itself and attack part of the body. Under normal circumstances, many T-cells and antibodies react with "self-reacted" peptides. One of the functions of specialised cells (located in the thymus and bone marrow) is to present young lymphocytes with the full body-produced antigens themselves, and to eliminate cells that identify themselves with antigens and inhibit autoimmunity.

paragraphs.context: Immunodeficiencies occur when one or more components of the immune system are inactive. The immune system’s ability to react to pathogens is impaired in both young and elderly patients, and the immune response begins to decline at about 50 years of age due to immunosensation. In developed countries, obesity, alcoholism and drug abuse are common causes of a weak immune system. However, malnutrition is the most common cause of immune deficiency in developing countries. Insufficient protein intake is associated with reduced cell-mediated immunity, complement activity, phagocyte activity, IgA antibody levels and cytokine production. In addition, early loss of thymus as a result of genetic mutation or surgical removal results in severe immunodeficiency and high susceptibility to infection.

paragraphs.context: Long-term active memory is obtained after infection by activating B and T cells. Active immunity can also be created artificially, through vaccination. The principle of vaccination (also called immunisation) is to introduce antigen from a pathogen to stimulate the immune system and develop specific immunity against that pathogen without causing any disease associated with that organism. This conscious immune response induction is successful because it utilizes the natural specificity of the immune system and its incubity. Infectious disease is still one of the most common causes of death in the human population, so vaccination is mankind’s most effective manipulation of the immune system.

paragraphs.context: The success of any pathogen depends on its ability to avoid an immune response. Therefore, pathogens developed several methods to infect the host while avoiding the detection or destruction of the immune system. Bacteria often overcome physical barriers by the excretion of enzymes that digest the barrier, for example by using the Type II secretion system. Alternatively, using the Type III secretion system, they can insert a hollow tube into the host cell, allowing the proteins to pass directly from the pathogen to the host cell. These proteins are often used to close the host defense.

paragraphs.context: In the mid-1950s Frank Burnet formulated Niels Jerne's proposal inspired by the Clonal Selection theory (CST) of immunity. Based on CST, Burnet developed a theory of how the immune response triggers itself and itself: "self-contained" components (body parts) do not trigger destructive immune responses, while "non-self-self-contained" communities (pathogens, allograft) trigger a destructive immune response. Later, the theory was modified to reflect new findings on histocompatibility or the complex activation of the "two characters" of T cells. The self-/non-self-theory of immunity and self-self-absorbing has been criticised, but it is still very influential.

paragraphs.context: Anti-inflammatory drugs are often used to control the effects of inflammation. Glucocorticoids are the most effective of these medicines. However, these medicines may have many unwanted side effects such as central obesity, hyperglycaemia, osteoporosis, and their use should be strictly controlled. Lower doses of NSAIDs are often used in combination with cytotoxic or immunosuppressive medicines such as methotrexate or azathioprine. Cytotoxic medicines inhibit the immune response by killing dividing cells, such as activated T cells. However, killing is random, and other cells and their organs that continue to divide are suffering, causing toxic side effects. Immunosuppressants, such as cyclosporin, prevent T cells from responding correctly to signals by blocking the transduction pathways of the signal.

paragraphs.context: On the other hand, various efector cells, such as cytotoxic natural killer cells and CTL cells (cytotoxic T-lymphocytes), are at their peak in order to achieve an effective response against all interfering pathogens. In active times, anti-inflammatory molecules such as cortisol and catecholamines are at their peak. There are two theories as to why an inflammatory space is reserved for bedtime. For one thing, inflammation would cause serious cognitive and physical disturbances if it occurred during the waking hours. Secondly, inflammation may occur during sleep due to the presence of melatonin. Inflammation causes a lot of oxidative stress, and the presence of melatonin in sleeptimes can actively prevent free radical production during this period.

paragraphs.context: When a T-cell meets a foreign pathogen, it expands the vitamin D receptor. This is mainly a signal device that allows the T-cell to bind to the active vitamin D form of steroid hormone calcitriol. T-cells have a symbiotic relationship with vitamin D. The T-cell not only expands the vitamin D receptor, which basically asks to bind to the steroid hormone version of vitamin D, calcitriol, but the T-cell expresses the gene CYP27B1, which is the gene responsible for converting vitamin D pre-hormone version, calcidiol, into a steroid hormone version, calcitriol. T-cells can perform their purpose only after they have committed to calcitriol. Other immune cells known to express CYP27B1 and thus activate vitamin D calcidiol include dendrite cells, keratinocytes and macrophages.

paragraphs.context: The development of an adaptive immune system occurred in the progeny of the jaws. Many of the classic molecules of the adaptive immune system (e.g. immunoglobulins and T-cell receptors) are only in the jaw. However, in primitive leukocyte-free vertebrates, such as the lamp and hamburger, a separate molecule is identified by lymphocytes. These animals have a wide range of molecules called variable lymphocyte receptors (VLRs) and, like jaw-refractory antigen receptors, they are produced from only a few genes. These molecules are believed to bind pathogenic antigens in the same way as antibodies and with the same specificity.

paragraphs.context: It is likely that a multi-component, adaptive immune system was created with the first vertebrates, since invertebrates do not produce lymphocytes or an antibody-based humoral response. However, many species use mechanisms that appear to be precursors of vertebrate immunity. The immune system even exists in structurally the simplest forms of life, where bacteria use a unique defense mechanism called a restricted modification system to protect against viral pathogens called bacteriophages. Procaryotes also have acquired immunity through a system that uses CRISPR sequences to preserve fragments of previously contacted phage genomes that can prevent viral replication in the form of RNA disorder. Single cell eukaryotes also contain offensive elements of the immune system, but their defence roles have been studied little.

paragraphs.context: Immunology is strongly experimental in practice, but it is also characterised by a continuous theoretical attitude. There have been many theories in immunology from the late 19th century to the present. At the end of the 19th century and at the beginning of the 20th century, there was a struggle between "cellular" and "humoral" immunity theories. In particular, according to the theory of immunity of the cell represented by Elie Metchnikoff, the cells that responded to the immune response — more specifically, phagocytes. Instead, the humorous immunity theory of Robert Koch and Emil von Behring found that active immune agents were soluble components (molecules) observed in organisms that were not its cells.

Tumour cells often contain fewer MHC class I molecules on their surface, leaving them undetected by killer cells. Some tumour cells also release anti-immune products, such as the secretion of cytokine TGF-β, which suppresses the activity of macrophages and lymphocytes. In addition, immune tolerance can develop against tumour antigens, so the immune system no longer attacks tumour cells.

paragraphs.context: Hypersensitivity is an immune response that damages your body’s own tissues. They are divided into four categories (type I – IV) based on the mechanisms and timing of the hypersensitivity reaction. Type I hypersensitivity is an immediate or anaphylactic reaction, often associated with an allergy. Symptoms may vary from mild discomfort to death. Type I hypersensitivity is mediated by IgE, which triggers the degranulation of mast cells and basophils in cross-links with antigen. Type II hypersensitivity occurs when antibodies bind to the patient’s own cells antigens, which means their destruction. This is also called antibody-dependent (or cytotoxic) hypersensitivity and is mediated by IgG and IgM antibodies. Immune complexes in different tissues (aggregations of antigens, complement proteins, IgG and IgM antibodies) trigger type III hypersensitivity reactions. Type IV hypersensitivity (also known as cell-mediated or delayed type hypersensitivity) usually develops within two to three days. Type IV reactions are related to many autoimmune and infectious diseases, but may also be associated with contact dermatitis (toxic ivy). Reactions are transmitted to T cells, monocytes and macrophages.

qas.question: What is the process by which pathogens evade the immune system by hiding inside the host cells called?

paragraphs.context: The rotational strategy used by several pathogens to avoid a congenital immune system is to hide in the cells of their host cells (also called intracellular pathogenesis). Here the pathogen spends most of its life cycle in host cells, where it protects itself from direct contact with immune cells, antibodies and complements. Some examples of intracellular pathogens are viruses, food poisoning bacteria Salmonella and eukaryotic parasites that cause malaria (Plasmodium falciparum) and leishmaniasis (Leishmania spp.). Other bacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, live inside a protective capsule, which prevents replenishment. Many pathogens secrete compounds that damage or misdirect the host’s immune response. Some bacteria form biofilms to protect the immune system from cells and proteins. Such biofilms occur in many successful infections, such as chronic infections with cystic fibrosis called Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Burkholder cenocepacia. Other bacteria produce surface proteins that bind to and render antibodies ineffective, such as Streptococcus (protein G), Staphylococcus aureus (protein A) and Peptostreptococcus magnus (protein L).

qas.question: What is the process by which the adaptive immune system is evaded by the chainging of non-essential epitopes called?

What is a parasite that always uses the same surface protein?

paragraphs.context: The mechanisms used to avoid an adaptive immune system are more complex. The simplest way is to quickly change the non-essential epitope on the surface of the pathogen (amino acids and/or sugars) while keeping the necessary epitopes hidden. This is called antigenic variation. An example is HIV, which is rapidly transformed, so the proteins in its virus shell that are necessary to get into its host cell are constantly changing. These repeated changes in antigens may explain the failure of vaccines directed at this virus. The parasite Trypanosoma brucei uses a similar strategy, constantly changing the surface protein type to another, allowing it to stay one step ahead of the antibody response. Covering antigens with host molecules is another common strategy to avoid the detection of the immune system. In HIV, the envelope that covers the virus consists of the outer membrane of the host cell; such "self-covering" viruses make it difficult for the immune system to identify them as "non-self-contained" structures.

paragraphs.context: Another important role in the immune system is the identification and removal of tumours. This is called immune control. The altered cells in the tumors express antigens that are not found in normal cells. For the immune system, these antigens appear to be foreign, and their presence causes immune cells to attack transformed tumour cells. Tumour-expressed antigens have several sources, some of which are derived from oncogen viruses, such as human papillomavirus, which causes cervical cancer, while others are the body’s own proteins that occur at low concentrations in normal cells but reach high tumour cell levels. One example is an enzyme called thyrosinase which, expressed at high concentrations, converts certain skin cells (e.g. melanocytes) into melanomas. A third potential source of tumour antigens is proteins, which are usually important for controlling cell growth and survival, and are usually converted into cancer-inducing molecules called oncogens.

paragraphs.context: Higher medicinal products (> 500 Da) may cause a neutralising immune response, especially when repeated or higher doses are administered. This limits the effectiveness of medicinal products based on higher peptides and proteins (typically greater than 6000 Da). In some cases, the medicine itself is not immunogenic but may be administered concomitantly with an immunogenic compound, as sometimes with Taxol. Calculation methods have been developed to predict the immunogenicity of peptides and proteins, as they are particularly useful in the design of therapeutic antibodies, the assessment of the likely virulence of mutations in viral layer particles and the validation of proposed peptide-based medicinal products. Early techniques were mainly based on the observation that hydrophilic amino acids are over-represented in epitopes as hydrophobic amino acids. However, recent developments are based on machine learning techniques using existing known epitope databases, usually based on well-researched viral proteins. A database has been set up to list epitope of pathogens known to be identified by B cells. The evolving field of immunogenicity studies based on bioinformatics is called immunoinformation. Immunoproteomics are used to study large proteins (proteomides) involved in immune response.

paragraphs.context: In addition to the negative effects of sleep deprivation, sleep and the entangled circular system have been shown to have a strong effect on immunological functions that affect both inborn and adaptive immunity. During the initial period of slow sleep, blood levels of cortisol, epinephrine and norepinephrine decreased abruptly, raising the levels of leptine, pituitary growth hormone and prolactin in the blood. These signals produce an inflammatory state by producing inflammatory cytokines interleukin-1, interleukin-12, TNF-alpha and IFN-gamma. These cytokines stimulate immune functions such as immune cell activation, proliferation and differentiation. It is during this period that undifferentiated or less differentiated, such as previously untreated and central memory T-cells, peak (i.e. during a slowly developing adaptive immune response). In addition to these effects, the number of hormones currently produced (leptine, pituitary growth hormone and prolactin) supports interactions between APC and T cells. It is also believed that this milieu will support the formation of long-term immune memory upon the onset of the Th1 immune response.

Even simple unicellular organisms, such as bacteria, have a primitive immune system, which are enzymes that protect against bacteriophages. Other basic immune mechanisms of antiquity eukaryotics have developed and survived in their present offspring, such as plants and invertebrates. Mutilated vertebrates, including humans, have more advanced defence mechanisms, including the ability to adapt over time to identify certain pathogens more effectively. paragraphs.context: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is a scientific intergovernmental body under the auspices of the UN established at the request of the Member States. It was first established in 1988 by two UN organisations, the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO) and the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), and later adopted by the United Nations General Assembly by Resolution 43/53. IPCC membership is open to all WMO and UNEP members. The IPCC produces reports supporting the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), which is the most important international climate agreement. The ultimate objective of the UNFCCC is to “stabilise greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere to a level that would prevent a dangerous man-made [man-made] disturbance in the climate system”. The IPCC reports cover "scientific, technical and socio-economic information relevant to the risk of man-made climate change, its potential impacts and the understanding of adaptation and mitigation options".

The law defines Parliament's legislative powers – areas in which it can legislate – by clearly defining the "reserved" powers for the UK Parliament. The Scottish Parliament has the power to legislate in all areas which are not specifically reserved for Westminster. The British Parliament retains its ability to change the powers of the Scottish Parliament and can extend or reduce the areas in which it can legislate. The sharp rise of nationalism in Scotland in the late 1960s fueled demands for some kind of home government or complete independence, and in 1969 the current Labour Government of Harold Wilson set up the Kilbrandon Commission to consider the British Constitution. Unlike many other parliamentary systems, Parliament elects the Prime Minister from several candidates at the beginning of each parliamentary term (after the general elections). Any Member may present his or her name as Prime Minister, and all Members of this House shall vote on it. Normally, the leader of the largest party will be returned to the Prime Minister and to the head of the Scottish Government. paragraphs.context: In Anglophonic academic works, theories of imperialism are often based on British experience. Opponents of the alleged aggressive and haughty imperialist policy of British Prime Minister Benjamin Disrael originally brought the term 'imperialism' to English in the late 1870s. Soon, supporters of imperialism, such as Joseph Chamberlain, caught it. To some, imperialism showed politics of idealism and goodwill, to others political selfishness, and more and more linked it to capitalist greed. Liberal John A. Hobson and Marxist Vladimir Lenin added a more theoretical macroeconomic mindset to the term. Lenin, in particular, had a significant influence on the later Marxist imperialist concepts of Imperialism, the highest stage of capitalism. Lenin described imperialism in his article as a natural extension of capitalism, which arose from the need for capitalist economies to continuously expand investment, material resources and labour in a way that required the expansion of the colonial region. Later Marxist theorists echo this notion of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism. Many theorists on the left have followed the structural or systemic nature of imperialism. Such writers have extended the term-related era so that it does not now mean politics or a short space of decades at the end of the 19th century, but a world system that extends centuries away and often returns to Christopher Columbus and, in some cases, to the Crusades. Once the use of the term has expanded, its significance has shifted to five distinct but often parallel axes: morality, economy, system, culture and time. These changes reflect, among other things, changes in sensuality, growing unrest, even clammy, accompanied by a fact of power, especially of Western power.

A significant factor in relief in this part of Warsaw is the edge of the moreen plain, called Warsaw Escarpment. paragraphs.context: The basic unit of the regional division of Poland is the municipality (gmina). The city is also a municipality – but with the city’s charter. Some larger cities are given rights, i.e. responsibilities and privileges, which belong to the second level of regional division – regions or powiates. In this case, we're talking about the district or the powiat grodzki. Such cities include Lublin, Krakow, Gdańsk and Poznań. In Warsaw, its regions also have some of the rights of Powiat – as has already been mentioned. paragraphs.context: The only thing that's directly affected by strong force is the elementary particles. However, nuclear power has been found to be the force between the Hadrons (the most familiar example is the force between the atomic nucleins). Here the strong force acts indirectly, passing on to the gluons, which are part of virtual pi- and rho-mesons that traditionally transmit nuclear power (see more on this subject). The failure of many searches of free quarks has shown that the elementary particles in question are not directly detectable. This phenomenon is called color isolation.

paragraphs.context: The weak force is due to the exchange of heavy W and Z-bosons. Its most known effect is the breakdown of beta (neutrons of atomic nucleins) and the associated radioactivity. The word "weak" is derived from the fact that field strength is about 1013 times lower than strong force. However, it is stronger than gravity in short distances. In addition, a consistent electroweak theory has been developed showing that electromagnetic and weak forces are inseparable at temperatures above 1015 Kelvin. Such temperatures have been studied in modern particle accelerators and show the conditions of the universe at the early moments of the Big Bang.

An example of normal force of action is the impact force on an object that collides with an immobile surface.

qas.question: Ideal strings transmit what delayed forces?

paragraphs.context: The tension forces can be modeled using ideal strings that are massless, smooth, unbreakable and unexpanded. They can be combined with ideal gadgets that allow ideal strings to change physical direction. Ideal threads transmit tension forces immediately in action-reaction pairs so that if two objects are connected together with an ideal thread, any force directed by the first object along the cord is followed by a force directed along the string in the opposite direction by another object. When the same string is connected several times by means of a fixation of circulars moving to the same object, the tension on the load can be multiplied. Another factor affecting the tensioning power of the springs affects the load on each load line. While such machines allow for increased force, the length of the rope increases accordingly to allow the load to be moved. These parallel effects eventually lead to the preservation of mechanical energy, because the work done with the load is the same regardless of how complex the machine is.

paragraphs.context: A conservative force operating in a closed system has a related mechanical work that allows energy to be transformed only between kinetics or possible forms. This means that in a closed system, net mechanical energy is stored whenever conservative force affects the system. The force is thus directly related to the separation of potential energy between two different places in space and can be regarded as an object of a potential field in the same way as the direction and amount of water flow can be regarded as an object of the contour map of the area’s elevation.

paragraphs.context: In certain physical scenarios, it is impossible to model forces because of the slope of potentials. This is often due to macrophysical considerations that produce forces generated by the macroscopic statistical average of the micro-states. For example, the friction is due to the slopes of several electrostatic possibilities between atoms, but it appears as a power model that is not independent of any macro-scan position vector. Other than conservative forces than friction are other contact forces, tension, compression and stretching. However, for a sufficiently detailed description, all these forces are the results of conservative forces, since each of these macroscopic forces is the net result of microscopic gradients.

qas.question: Conservative forces are often associated with the transfer of what?

paragraphs.context: The relationship between macroscopic conservative forces and microscopic conservative forces is described with detailed treatment by statistical mechanics. In macroscopic closed systems, conservative forces work to alter the system's internal energies and are often associated with heat transfer. According to the second law of thermodynamics, conservative forces lead to energy changes in closed systems from more random circumstances ordered as entropy grows.

qas.question: What is the kilogram-force sometimes reffered to as?

paragraphs.context: The weight of the pound is a metric equivalent less than the weight of the newton: kg (kgf) (sometimes kilopond) is the force obtained by the standard gravity of one kilogram of mass. The force of the weight kg leads to an alternative but rarely used mass unit: a metre bullet (sometimes a cup or casing) is the mass which accelerates 1 m·s−2 when subjected to a force of 1 kgf. Gravity is not part of the modern SI system and is generally degraded, but it nevertheless considers the use for some purposes to be an expression of aircraft weight, jet thrust, wheel talk, torque and engine torque. Other arcane forces are the Sthène corresponding to 1000 N and the Kip corresponding to 1000 lbf.
